componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Travis in the 2 LDCs, they really get handled through mechanisms in different ways. So in North Carolina, there's the decouple or that handles any change in consumption and weather, et cetera, and it doesn't handle rate base, which is why we ha
componenttext: Yes. Well, Travis in the 2 LDCs, they really get handled through mechanisms in different ways. So in North Carolina, there's the decouple or that handles any change in consumption and weather, et cetera, and it doesn't handle rate base, which is why we have a rate case that we filed there now. In South Carolina we have the Rate Stabilization Act, which is basically a streamlined rate review that happened there for every repeating season at the end of March. And if there's more than 50 basis points variance and suggested in November. So it's really considered through both those mechanisms, even though they differ a little in their process.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I'd say -- I wouldn't say a lot more than what we planned. So what we've got into plan contemplates it. So in North Carolina South Carolina, they differ somewhat. In South Carolina, we own very little of the transmission system. Of course, we u
componenttext: Yes. Well, I'd say -- I wouldn't say a lot more than what we planned. So what we've got into plan contemplates it. So in North Carolina South Carolina, they differ somewhat. In South Carolina, we own very little of the transmission system. Of course, we used to own more of it through a different subsidiary but we sold that a year ago. There's still some transmission in the South Carolina Electric and Gas, gas system, but it's not a tremendous amount. There's certainly distribution growth there in the South Carolina system, but that's not a significant amount above and beyond the depreciation that applies to that business each year. In North Carolina, it's a different story because of significant transmission enhancements that are going on. I actually visited one of those projects a couple of weeks ago, and it's a significant pipeline investment that's going on, and it's going extremely well. The majority of it own existing right-of-way in the Western North Carolina.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and that could lead to distribution investment options?
componenttext: Okay, and that could lead to distribution investment options?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the majority of this is related to growth in the territory. The areas we serve are growing very well. A lot of transmission enhancement in the next couple of years will be up in the research triangle area, too, in additional Western North Car
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the majority of this is related to growth in the territory. The areas we serve are growing very well. A lot of transmission enhancement in the next couple of years will be up in the research triangle area, too, in additional Western North Carolina because a lot of the industrials are really going, for example, the research universities are all going to complete gas supply as opposed to other fuels. So I don't know there's tremendous new frontier kind of distribution opportunities, but I think there's a lot of industrials that are really pushing it. Electric fired, gas-fired, electric generation, too.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Dan Jenkins, State of Wisconsin Investment Board.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Dan Jenkins, State of Wisconsin Investment Board.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give a little color on the -- you had a $0.04 year-over-year for O&M, and I just wondering is that -- what's driving that? Is that timing? Or is that something that's going to continue on a comparison basis going forward?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give a little color on the -- you had a $0.04 year-over-year for O&M, and I just wondering is that -- what's driving that? Is that timing? Or is that something that's going to continue on a comparison basis going forward?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's fairly consistent with our general budget. It is a little more lumpy there in the first quarter. We don't expect it to be that significant throughout the year. The most significant thing is we make compensation adjustments in the middle of the fi
componenttext: No, it's fairly consistent with our general budget. It is a little more lumpy there in the first quarter. We don't expect it to be that significant throughout the year. The most significant thing is we make compensation adjustments in the middle of the first quarter. So you've got some of that coming through. And also of the incentive-based compensation, the part that's driven by -- that's driven off share price has obviously been more than we had expected, and I guess, that's a high-class problem to have with the stock performing pretty well especially against the peer group over the last quarter.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I think you mentioned on the nuclear that the current critical path item is the shield-building and I know that in your report that you filed in February that was mentioned there as well as was wondering if you could update us on the status
componenttext: Okay. And then I think you mentioned on the nuclear that the current critical path item is the shield-building and I know that in your report that you filed in February that was mentioned there as well as was wondering if you could update us on the status of that and in terms of the components that are being fabricated and so forth.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, the shield-building is going probably better than we had anticipated. Our concern for the shield-building really came from the contractor, their concerns at the time bridge and iron. Now Fluor has taken over, but we still retain the CB&I service
componenttext: Yes, Dan, the shield-building is going probably better than we had anticipated. Our concern for the shield-building really came from the contractor, their concerns at the time bridge and iron. Now Fluor has taken over, but we still retain the CB&I services crew that is doing that welding. So even though CB&I power exited the consortium, the CB&I services folks who are doing the containment vessel welding and the shield-building welding stay, and they're doing a tremendous job. So we've got -- there's about 16 courses of this steel that goes up to form this shield-building. You lay a course at a time, weld it together then fill that course with concrete. So we've got 3 of those courses that have been placed, welded and filled with concrete. The fourth course has been placed. It's being welded. We anticipate filling that with concrete sometime in the next couple of weeks. Deliveries are coming in from an entity called Newport News Industrial, NNI, icon in Virginia, and those folks are working very hard to meet our schedule, and we're looking at diversifying that supply chain a little bit but perhaps moving some of those modules to another vendor to free up a little bit of space at NNI. So overall, I'd say this shield-building has gone a little bit better than we expected.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: How many of those components are you still waiting on shield-building?
componenttext: How many of those components are you still waiting on shield-building?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say there's 4 [ph] -- the first unit, Unit 2, we've probably got 2/3 of the shield-building panels that we need. And for the trailing unit, Unit 3, we probably only have about 1/3 of them, and so we're still waiting on about 2/3.
componenttext: I would say there's 4 [ph] -- the first unit, Unit 2, we've probably got 2/3 of the shield-building panels that we need. And for the trailing unit, Unit 3, we probably only have about 1/3 of them, and so we're still waiting on about 2/3.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then on Unit 3, what's the current critical path items for that unit?

componenttext: It runs through the shield-building as well, Dan. So it's still shield-building either unit we're talking about it runs through shield-building.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Paul Patterson, Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: The next question is from Paul Patterson, Glenrock Associates.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask you about the fixed price option. And if you were to select that, what the impact is in terms of -- does it change the way the payments would go? Could you just elaborate a little more on that?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask you about the fixed price option. And if you were to select that, what the impact is in terms of -- does it change the way the payments would go? Could you just elaborate a little more on that?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, from a payment perspective, Jimmy alluded to earlier, we are changing the way that we make the payments heretofore. We've had payments based on either hitting milestones or what we call progress payments. Progress payments is a bit of a misnome
componenttext: Yes, Paul, from a payment perspective, Jimmy alluded to earlier, we are changing the way that we make the payments heretofore. We've had payments based on either hitting milestones or what we call progress payments. Progress payments is a bit of a misnomer. It really wasn't tied to cash flow progress. So we've changed that and when we go forward, we are negotiating a milestone payment schedule. So it's a construction milestone payment schedule, which will have us paying only for milestones achieved.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, but it means, I guess, what I'm wondering is in terms of the -- you guys have not decided on whether or not given out fixed price option. Is that correct?
componenttext: Okay, but it means, I guess, what I'm wondering is in terms of the -- you guys have not decided on whether or not given out fixed price option. Is that correct?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and if you were to go for it, does that change the payments? Or does that change the scheduling payments? Do you pay anything upfront? Or is it pretty much the same way we should be paid over the same time frame pretty much the same amount with this
componenttext: Okay, and if you were to go for it, does that change the payments? Or does that change the scheduling payments? Do you pay anything upfront? Or is it pretty much the same way we should be paid over the same time frame pretty much the same amount with this milestone? That's it.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Paul, what we've done we've got an estimate for what is the nonfixed price option. If we elect the fixed price option, there's an added cost that comes with taking that risk away, if you will, and so we'll just pay that additional costs. It'll be
componenttext: Yes. So Paul, what we've done we've got an estimate for what is the nonfixed price option. If we elect the fixed price option, there's an added cost that comes with taking that risk away, if you will, and so we'll just pay that additional costs. It'll be stretched out over the entire project. So there's -- it won't necessarily be front end loaded. We're just picking the milestones, which indicate real progress. We'll attach payments to those milestones, and when the Westinghouse hits those milestones, we'll make payment to them, but the additional cost just get spread out over the remainder of the project.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Andy Levi at Avon Capital.
componenttext: The next question is from Andy Levi at Avon Capital.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'm just going to go back to Toshiba because I want to get something clarified because if you were to choose the fixed cost option, which seems to be the right way to go and obviously, you've got rid of CBI. So that was a very good thing that you
componenttext: I guess, I'm just going to go back to Toshiba because I want to get something clarified because if you were to choose the fixed cost option, which seems to be the right way to go and obviously, you've got rid of CBI. So that was a very good thing that you guys did and have Fluor in there. But given Toshiba's continued financial issues and concern about the companies or our concerns and I guess, sell-side analyst concerns about the long-term viability of the company, can you tell us what type of projections you have in place to protect SCANA in a similar project from Toshiba's potential insolvency relative to the fixed cost contract and their ability to execute on that? And then can you get more into the surety bond that you have, the amount that you have and how that would work if you had to call on that because we saw Portland General having to call on their surety bond with, and it wasn't that simple.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andy, this is Steve. Let me start. I'll let Jimmy to maybe finish a little bit on the surety bond, but the surety bond as you pointed out earlier was there really to create kind of a soft landing. So it would pay vendors that were in process and allow us
componenttext: Andy, this is Steve. Let me start. I'll let Jimmy to maybe finish a little bit on the surety bond, but the surety bond as you pointed out earlier was there really to create kind of a soft landing. So it would pay vendors that were in process and allow us to, in a systematic, logical fashion, wind the project down to the point where Toshiba and/or Westinghouse could exit. Now if we're presuming some kind of insolvency or bankruptcy, you'd also have to presume that Westinghouse doesn't survive that, and so as with that provision then as you're aware, there can be various kinds of bankruptcy and it doesn't necessarily mean that the contractor stops working but -- so we are working hard to make sure that we're not in advance of payments and then we have information, which includes source codes, software and proprietary design information that's being escrowed, and the bankruptcy or insolvency would be one of the triggers that gives me that information and then we would look to finish the plan on our own. We could do that one of a couple of ways. We could either act as our own general contractor, which we'd be more comfortable doing now than we originally signed up for the project since we've made so much progress, and we understand that this construction progress. And we would go out and get a subcontracted construction vendor, presumably Fluor, since they're already on-site, already familiar with that means and methods, now the project or we could EPC it again. So we could give it to an EPC contractors. Certainly Fluor would be in a good position. They are an EPC contractor. So we could give it to them. So the important part to me is that I have the information that I need to be able to finish the plans on my own, and that's whole reason why we're escrowing.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I guess, the issue that I see though is, I guess, the thing that was a big positive was this fixed costs contract, right? Because it kind of eliminates sharing downside above the $500 million escalation in the cost of the contract, and so is that cont
componenttext: But I guess, the issue that I see though is, I guess, the thing that was a big positive was this fixed costs contract, right? Because it kind of eliminates sharing downside above the $500 million escalation in the cost of the contract, and so is that contract is within entity that is not a good counterparty, that fixed cost contract is not really worth a lot, I guess, and that's what I'm really getting at is not as much the ability to finish the plan or construction aspect of it, but the ability to control the costs if in a negative case, Toshiba doesn't have the money to pay above the $500 million escalation that you're willing to pay in a fixed cost option.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier, Andy, what we have on our side, though, is sometime to watch how they progress and to see how that's going. We've got another 6 months before we got to make this call. They have said publicly that this business is one of 3 key are
componenttext: Well, as I said earlier, Andy, what we have on our side, though, is sometime to watch how they progress and to see how that's going. We've got another 6 months before we got to make this call. They have said publicly that this business is one of 3 key areas of focus for them, and they're shedding the other businesses. They brought in $6.5 billion sales close here shortly. Everything they said they're going to do, it appears they've done to this point in our very efficient manner. So we've got several more months to watch this and monitor the situation.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just get concerns stock trading a little over $1, and then just on the surety bond, could you just go over that and the amount of that and how that would work, and who would be paying you?
componenttext: Just get concerns stock trading a little over $1, and then just on the surety bond, could you just go over that and the amount of that and how that would work, and who would be paying you?

componenttext: Yes, and so it's actually we -- it can be either in surety bond or letters of credit. We've allowed them to provide that through letters of credit, and we're comfortable with counterparties there, and it is an annual calculation based upon the estimated payments quarterly in the next year. So we've made that calculation for 2016. We've elected it, and those letters of credit are in place now.

componenttext: And that's for $100 million? Is that for $100 million?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: It's at a maximum of $100 million based upon the projected cash flows of the year that's applicable, and so it will change each year.

componenttext: So at SCE&G, David, we're consistent on the base business at above 9% is our strategy to state out of any base rate increases outside of the BLRA. And the BLRA of course, is at 10.5%, and at PSNC, we've got a current allowed 10.6%.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Andrew Weisel of Macquarie Capital.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to clarify timing of this nuclear fixed option if you do exercise it or not. It seems to me like Larry couple of different steps here, and I was just want to understand when we can expect each and in what order. So you're going to make a decis
componenttext: I just want to clarify timing of this nuclear fixed option if you do exercise it or not. It seems to me like Larry couple of different steps here, and I was just want to understand when we can expect each and in what order. So you're going to make a decision. You're going to file with regulators. You're going to tell us about it, and you're going to officially exercise the option with the contractors. Is that the right order? And what might the time line of those 4 pieces look like?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to make that decision sometime in the second quarter. Then we will file between the filing and the Public Service Commission rendering an opinion is 6 months, and in that intervening 6 months, we will file testimony. So testimony filed for any
componenttext: We're going to make that decision sometime in the second quarter. Then we will file between the filing and the Public Service Commission rendering an opinion is 6 months, and in that intervening 6 months, we will file testimony. So testimony filed for any intervenors, and then we'll have a hearing, which will be a public hearing. We will -- we have until November 1 to let Westinghouse know whether we have opted for that fixed price option, and we can do that basically any time from now until November 1.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will just add we're going to let you know exactly and currently the time we file.
componenttext: I will just add we're going to let you know exactly and currently the time we file.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the filing could come very shortly after you make your decision, and that process can be underway by the time you officially exercise the option with Westinghouse?
componenttext: Okay. So the filing could come very shortly after you make your decision, and that process can be underway by the time you officially exercise the option with Westinghouse?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would think that it would be well underway before we officially exercise the option with Westinghouse because the option with Westinghouse is subject to regulatory approval.
componenttext: Yes, I would think that it would be well underway before we officially exercise the option with Westinghouse because the option with Westinghouse is subject to regulatory approval.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, good point. And then in terms of updating the CapEx and financing costs, would that come -- would that uptake come only than as quickly earnings call or potentially when you announce to us that you made a decision in our filing with regulators one
componenttext: Right, good point. And then in terms of updating the CapEx and financing costs, would that come -- would that uptake come only than as quickly earnings call or potentially when you announce to us that you made a decision in our filing with regulators one way or the other?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there's 2 different moving parts there. One is which option do we go with just the amended contract or we go with fixed option. The second moving parts of that is getting the revised payment schedule worked out between us and the contractor. So th
componenttext: Yes. So there's 2 different moving parts there. One is which option do we go with just the amended contract or we go with fixed option. The second moving parts of that is getting the revised payment schedule worked out between us and the contractor. So those 2 don't necessarily happen at the same time. So it may be that we are in a position and make the filing and notify you of which option we've chosen, but haven't yet completely agreed on the payment schedules. So we can't completely update the CapEx schedule until we get both of those done.

componenttext: I don't know a firm answer on that, I mean, because it could be that we have to use this option of the -- I don't know this, but it could be we have to use this resolution board to resolve any differences we have there. So that could add some time on the end of it, but I would hope all of that we would, Steve, is it reasonable to say we hope to get all that done this year?

componenttext: Yes, absolutely.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't know anything at this point that says we need any equity until 2017 at the earliest. Recall we sold these 2 subsidiaries last year, realized about $425-plus million of cash after tax from that. So in the short term, we've used to that to defray s
componenttext: We don't know anything at this point that says we need any equity until 2017 at the earliest. Recall we sold these 2 subsidiaries last year, realized about $425-plus million of cash after tax from that. So in the short term, we've used to that to defray some debt, but we've got plenty of that to sustain us through 2015 (sic) [ 2016 ].

componenttext: Yes, excuse me, 2016. Again, I don't know what the revised payment schedule's going to be. So we just don't have that at this point. So we would have to have that, but nothing we know at this point says we've got anything additional related to that. As Steve said earlier, we're planning on paying the if we elected the fixed price, we would pay that ratably over the remaining life of the construction. It's not a lump payment.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, and we look forward to finalizing this decision on the fixed price option and the subsequent petition to be filed with the PSC. We continue to focus on our new nuclear construction and on our operating all of our businesses in a safe and
componenttext: Well, thank you, and we look forward to finalizing this decision on the fixed price option and the subsequent petition to be filed with the PSC. We continue to focus on our new nuclear construction and on our operating all of our businesses in a safe and reliable manner, and we thank you for joining us today and for your interest in SCANA. Have a good day.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the SCANA Corporation Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference c
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the SCANA Corporation Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded on Thursday, April 28, 2016. Anyone who does not consent to the taping may drop off the line. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Susan Wright, Director of Financial Planning and Investor Relations.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to our analyst call. As you know, earlier today, we announced financial results for the first quarter of 2016. Joining us on the call today are: Jimmy Addison, SCANA's Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Byrne, Chief Operating Office
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to our analyst call. As you know, earlier today, we announced financial results for the first quarter of 2016. Joining us on the call today are: Jimmy Addison, SCANA's Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Byrne, Chief Operating Officer of SCE&G. During the call, Jimmy will provide an overview of our financial results. Steve will provide an update on our new nuclear project. After our comments, we will respond to your questions.
The slides and the earnings release referred to in this call are available at scana.com.
Additionally, we post information related to our new nuclear project and other investor information directly to our website at scana.com. On SCANA's home page, there is a yellow box containing links to the nuclear development and other investor information sections of the website. It is possible that some of the information that we will be posting from time to time may be deemed material information that has not otherwise become public.
You can sign up for email alerts under the Investors section of scana.com to notify you when there is a new posting in the nuclear development and/or Other Investor Information sections of the website.
Finally, before I turn the call over to Jimmy, I would like to remind you that certain statements that may be made during today's call are considered forward-looking statements and are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties as shown on Slide 2.
The company does not recognize an obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
Additionally, we may disclose certain non-GAAP measures during this presentation, and the required Reg G information can be found in the Investors section of our website under Webcasts & Presentations.
I will now turn the call over to Jimmy.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Susan, and thank you all for joining us today. I'll begin our earnings discussion on Slide 3. GAAP earnings in the first quarter of 2016 were $1.23 per share compared to $2.80 per share in the same quarter of 2015. Excluding the net-of-tax gains o
componenttext:
Thanks, Susan, and thank you all for joining us today. I'll begin our earnings discussion on Slide 3. GAAP earnings in the first quarter of 2016 were $1.23 per share compared to $2.80 per share in the same quarter of 2015. Excluding the net-of-tax gains on the sales of CGT and SCI, positive earnings drivers from electric margins, primarily due to a Base Load Review Act rate increase and customer growth, as well as the positive impact of the depreciation study were more than offset by the negative impact of weather on both electric margins as well as on gas margins in our Georgia business. 
Gas margins were also down due to CGT operating for a month during the first quarter of 2015 before it was sold. Additionally, expected increases in O&M expenses in CapEx-related items, including interest and property taxes, had a negative impact on earnings. 
At the bottom of the slide, you will note that abnormal weather decreased electric margins by $0.05 per share in the first quarter of 2016 and increased electric margins by $0.05 per share in the first quarter of 2015, resulting in a $0.10 per share negative swing. 
Slide 4 shows earnings on a GAAP-adjusted, weather-normalized basis. Earnings in the first quarter of 2016 were $1.28 per share compared to $1.34 per share in the same quarter of 2015. As a reminder, GAAP-adjusted, weather-normalized EPS excludes the impact of abnormal weather on electric margins and the net-of-tax gains on the sales of CGT and SCI from the first quarter of 2015. Abnormal weather on gas margins is not adjusted in this measure as gas margins are weather-normalized for the North and South Carolina gas businesses, and the direct impact of abnormal weather on the Georgia business is generally insignificant on an annual basis. 
Now on Slide 5, I'd like to briefly review results for our principal lines of business. On a GAAP basis, South Carolina Electric and Gas Company's first quarter 2016 earnings were down $0.08 per share compared to the same period of 2015. The decrease in earnings is due to lower electric margins, principally as a result of abnormal weather in both periods, as well as higher O&M expenses and higher expenses related to our capital program, including interest expense and property taxes. These decreases more than offset increases from the continued recovery of financing cost under the BLRA, customer growth, both the electric and gas businesses and the application of the previously mentioned new depreciation rates. 
PSNC Energy reported earnings of $0.25 per share in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $0.24 per share in the same quarter of the prior year, primarily due to higher margins from customer growth. SCANA Energy, which includes SCANA Energy Marketing and SCANA Energy Georgia, showed a decrease in first quarter earnings of $0.06 per share, primarily due to lower throughput attributable to the warmer weather during the first quarter of 2016 as compared to 2015 and higher transportation cost.
On a GAAP basis, SCANA's corporate and other businesses reported relatively flat earnings in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $1.44 per share in the comparative quarter of the prior year. Excluding the net-of-tax gains on the sales of CGT and SCI of $1.41 per share, GAAP-adjusted, weather-normalized EPS was down $0.03, due primarily to foregone earnings contributed by CGT and SCI prior to the closing of the sales in the first quarter of 2015. 
I would now like to touch on economic trends in our service territory on Slide 6. The Carolinas continue to have a favorable business environment, and we are pleased by the continuous growth in our service territories as evidenced by announcements to invest approximately $380 million, with the expectation of creating approximately 1,300 jobs. At the bottom of the slide, you can see the national unemployment rate along with the rates for the 3 states where SCANA has a presence and the SCE&G electric territory. South Carolina's unemployment rate is now at 5.7%, and the rate in SCE&G's electric territory is estimated at 5%. Of particular interest and attesting to our state's strong economic growth, almost 80,000 or 3.7% more South Carolinians are working today than a year ago. 
Slide 7 presents customer growth in electric sales statistics. On the top half of the slide is the customer growth rate for each of our regulated businesses. SCE&G's electric business added customers at a year-over-year rate of 1.5%. Our regulated gas businesses in North and South Carolina added customers at a rate of 2.5% and 2.7%, respectively. We continue to see strong customer growth in our businesses and in the region. 
The bottom table outlines our actual and weather-normalized kilowatt-hour sales for the 12 months ended March 31, 2016. Overall, weather-normalized total retail sales were up 1.3% on a 12-month ended basis. 
Now please turn to Slide 8, which recaps our regulatory rate base and returns. The pie chart on the left presents the components of our regulated rate base of approximately $9.5 billion. As noted in the 2 shades of blue, approximately 86% of this rate base is related to the electric business. 
In the block on the right, you will see SCE&G's base electric business, in which we're allowed a 10.25% return on equity. The earned return for the 12 months ended March 31, 2016, in the base electric business continues at approximately 9.75%, meeting our stated goal of earning a return of 9% or higher to prevent the need for non-BLRA-related base rate increases during the peak nuclear construction years. 
We continue to be pleased with the execution of our strategy. As a reminder, we're allowed a return on equity of 10.25% in our LDC in South Carolina and if the earned ROE of the gas business for the 12 months ending March 31 falls outside a range of 50 basis points above or below the allowed ROE, then we will file to adjust rates under the Rate Stabilization Act in June. As of December 31, 2015, the 12-month earned return for SCE&G gas was 9.65%. 
As you are aware, we recently filed an application with the North Carolina Utilities Commission requesting an annual revenue increase of $41.6 million at PSNC Energy in response to the normal attrition in the earned returns in that business. This rate increase is the result of PSNC's need to recover cost to operate and expand its pipeline system and to implement a pipeline integrity management rider. This rider would allow PSNC to track and receive ongoing recovery of capital expenses related to its distribution and transmission pipeline integrity management programs. 
Slide 9 presents our CapEx forecast. This forecast reflects the company's current estimate of new nuclear spending through 2018 and is consistent with last quarter's call and the February quarterly BLRA report, which also reflects the amended EPC agreement that was announced in October of 2015. 
At the bottom of the slide, we recap the estimated new nuclear CWIP from July 1 through June 30 to correspond to the periods on which the BLRA rate increases are historically calculated. 
Slide 10 presents the transition payments information and an expected time frame for the filing with the Public Service Commission of South Carolina. Once these events are complete, we will update the CapEx schedule and the corresponding financing plan. 
Now please turn to Slide 11 to review our estimated financing plan through 2018. As a reminder, we have switched to open market purchases instead of issuing new shares to fulfill our 401(k) and DRIP plans, at least until we have fully utilized the net cash proceeds from the sales of CGT and SCI. We do not anticipate the need for further equity issuances until 2017. The election of the fixed-price option would likely change planned equity issuances after 2016. 
It is unlikely that these issuances will occur in the exact amounts or timing as presented, as they are subject to changes in our funding needs for planned project expenses. We continue to adjust the financing to match the related project CapEx on a 50-50 debt and equity basis. 
Now on Slide 12, we are reaffirming our 2016 GAAP-adjusted, weather-normalized earnings guidance as $3.90 per share to $4.10 per share with an internal target of $4 per share. Our long-term GAAP-adjusted, weather-normalized average annual growth guidance target remains unchanged as we plan to deliver 4% to 6% earnings growth over 3 to 5 years, using a base of 2015's GAAP-adjusted, weather-normalized EPS of $3.73. 
I'll now turn the call over to Steve to provide an update on our nuclear project.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jimmy. I'd like to begin by addressing the status of the settlement with the consortium and the PSC approval process. Slide 13 presents the settlement agreement outline that we have previously shown. Westinghouse closed on the transaction to acq
componenttext:
Thanks, Jimmy. I'd like to begin by addressing the status of the settlement with the consortium and the PSC approval process. 
Slide 13 presents the settlement agreement outline that we have previously shown. Westinghouse closed on the transaction to acquire Stone & Webster from CB&I at the end of December. Fluor began work as the subcontracted construction manager for the new nuclear construction site on January 4. The Kraft employees transitioned to Fluor on April 4. 
While Slide 13 presents cost as of the settlement date, in our next quarterly BLRA update filing to be filed in the next couple of weeks, we plan to update the project costs for estimated change orders, primarily related items listed in Exhibit C of the settlement agreement. As you may recall, Exhibit C described items not resolved in net settlement. 
Listed on Slide 14 are several of those items for which we now have estimated the cost. Also listed are the estimated change orders associated with escrowing the software and documentation necessary to complete the project and new change orders initiated since the settlement that are owner directed. Additional sales tax, which has been excluded from the fixed price option, is also listed. 
Slide 15 presents the relative schedules of both the filing of an update petition and the annual request for revised rates. We continue our analysis of the fixed price option, and we'll consider any input received from Fluor. 
As a reminder, we have until November 1 of this year to unilaterally elect the fixed price option. Regardless of which scenario we choose, once a decision has been made, we will file a petition with the Public Service Commission to amend the capital cost and schedule for the project. We continue to expect to reach a conclusion on the matter sometime during the second quarter, and expect to have a minor delay of a few weeks in filing our annual request for revised rates under the BLRA in order to coordinate the petition with the revised rates application. 
Moving on to some of the activities at the new nuclear construction site. Fluor's integration into the project as Westinghouse's subcontracted construction manager continues to progress, with the placement of managers in key positions of the construction areas in a series of assessments that are taking place to streamline processes and improvement -- I'm sorry, improve performance. 
Slide 16 presents an aerial photo of the site from September of 2015. This photo gives you a view of the layout of the site, and I've labeled both Units 2 and 3, as well as many other areas of the construction site. 
Slide 17 presents a schematic view of the 5 large structural modules that are located inside the containment vessel. This expanded view gives you a better feel for how CA-01 through 05 fits spatially inside of the containment vessel. As you will recall, we have now placed CA-01, CA-04 and CA-05 for Unit 2, and CA-04 for Unit 3. 
Slide 18 shows an aerial view of the Unit 2 containment. Looking down into the containment vessel, you see the first ring section with openings or penetrations sitting on top of the lower bowl. The previously mentioned CA-01, CA-04 and CA-05 have been placed, and can be seen in the picture. 
Slide 19 shows a picture of the Unit 2 CA-02 module. CA-02 is a wall section that forms part of the in-containment refueling water storage tank. As mentioned in previous quarters, CA-02 is now structurally complete and is awaiting installation. 
Slide 20 shows a picture of the Unit 2 CA-03, which is the west wall of the in-containment refueling water storage tank. Fabrication continues as all 17 of CA-03 submodules are on site and standing on the assembly platform. 
Slide 21 shows a picture of the first portion of the Unit 3 module CA20, which was placed during March. This module consists of 4 subassemblies, and the decision was made to expedite placement of subassemblies 3 and 4 as they allow for work to move forward that is required in order to begin shield building erection, which is the next critical path item. 
As you can see on Slide 22, fabrication continues on subassemblies 1 and 2 inside of the module assembly building or MAB. All 72 required submodules are on site. These remaining subassemblies will be placed once they are completed. As a reminder, CA-20 is an auxiliary building module that is located outside and adjacent to the containment vessel. 
Slide 23 shows a picture of the Unit 3 containment vessel ring 1 placement. Ring 1 was placed on top of the containment vessel lower bowl on April 13. 
Slide 24 shows a picture of the Unit 3 module CA-05. This module comprises one of the major wall sections within the containment vessel. Fabrication of the Unit 3 CA-05 has been completed, and it has been staged outside of the MAB. 
Slide 25 shows a picture of the beginnings of the Unit 3 module CA-01. Module CA-01 houses the steam generators and the pressurizer and forms the refueling canal inside the containment vessel. Currently, we have 24 of the 47 submodules on site. Seven of those submodules are upright and being welded together in the MAB. 
Now turn to Slide #26. I want to briefly mention that last week, the Public Service Commission of South Carolina approved SCE&G's request to reduce its electric rates to reflect lower fuel costs. Having a balanced and diversified fuel mix contributes to a fuel cost that will be passed on to our customers. It is anticipated that this decrease should more than offset any decrease to residential customers from the BLRA for the year. 
Finally, please now turn to Slide #27 to discuss some of the SCE&G solar initiatives. Under South Carolina law, or Act 236, we are allowed to recover certain costs associated with our efforts to implement renewable energy incentive programs. We officially rolled out our DER program in August of 2015, with the goal of adding approximately 84 megawatts of renewable generating facilities to our system by the end of 2020. We anticipate being almost halfway to our 2020 goal by the end of 2016. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. We'll now be glad to spend respond to any questions you might have.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Jim von Riesemann at Mizuho Securities.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really just ask the elephant in the quest -- room. There's been a lot of these conflicting signals in the marketplace about Toshiba, and investors are obviously expressing some concern here. So with that being said, how are you -- how does the fluidity of
componenttext: Really just ask the elephant in the quest -- room. There's been a lot of these conflicting signals in the marketplace about Toshiba, and investors are obviously expressing some concern here. So with that being said, how are you -- how does the fluidity of their situation affect your calculus with potentially accepting the fixed price option?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're certainly monitoring the situation to the extent that we can get public information about it. I think the things that are important for our consideration are, unlike the previous contract, where we had certain calendar-based payments, in the n
componenttext: Well, we're certainly monitoring the situation to the extent that we can get public information about it. I think the things that are important for our consideration are, unlike the previous contract, where we had certain calendar-based payments, in the new arrangement, we're only paying for work completed. So we should be in a good kind of an equivalent cash flow situation compared to the work completed and not be behind or, if you will, ahead on the cash payments at any point in time from here through to completion. So it's really the progress payments are aligning with the work as it's completed. We are also very focused on the next 6 months. We've got 6 more months before we have to make that decision. And while we'll likely file before then, we don't have to make the technical election with Toshiba until that point. So we plan to monitor the situation. Of course, they've taken some actions already on disposing some of their noncore assets. They've said that this business is core to them, and they have backed that up with the decisions they've made to this point. So it's obviously dynamic, Jim, and we're going to continue to monitor it over the next several months.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's safe to say that you're not worried, though? Is that what I'm hearing you say?
componenttext: It's safe to say that you're not worried, though? Is that what I'm hearing you say?

componenttext: I mean, no, it's certainly something we're monitoring. It -- we're paying attention to it, but it's -- I wouldn't say it's a worry, no.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, we think we'll have made our decision, as we said before, in the second quarter. We anticipate the filing for both in the second quarter. We just want to make sure that we align one filing with the other. They're slightly different time frames.
componenttext: Yes, Jim, we think we'll have made our decision, as we said before, in the second quarter. We anticipate the filing for both in the second quarter. We just want to make sure that we align one filing with the other. They're slightly different time frames. The update petition has, by law, 6 months before a decision has to be rendered by the Public Service Commission. The annual BLRA filing is a 5-month time frame. So we don't want -- we would like them to be aligned with each other.

componenttext: Yes, well, our strategy hasn't changed, and that's correct. We expect to finance roughly half and half with debt and equity between the two. What we don't know at this point is, when will we need it. If we go that direction, we've got to wait until we sort out the progress payment schedule.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, we think that, that's progressing fairly well according to their latest announced plans. We anticipate that they are getting close to doing the coal hydro. So their reactive cooling pumps have been installed, which was the last thing that they we
componenttext: Stephen, we think that, that's progressing fairly well according to their latest announced plans. We anticipate that they are getting close to doing the coal hydro. So their reactive cooling pumps have been installed, which was the last thing that they were waiting for at Sanmen Unit 1. They're planning calls for them to load the fuel yet this year. So sometime, probably in the late third or early fourth quarter. And then, the testing, from that point, is really up to the utility. So it's less in Westinghouse hands than it is the utility's hands, but certainly some time we think, early next year, I'm not sure if going commercial is the appropriate term for China, but they'll be on a grid making power.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked. But if you guys can talk a little bit about the pipeline integrity program you guys have asked for. What is the size and scope? How long do you expect that program to last for?
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked. But if you guys can talk a little bit about the pipeline integrity program you guys have asked for. What is the size and scope? How long do you expect that program to last for?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's in our capital that we disclosed there for the 3 years, there's a good bit of integrity management related in that entire CapEx period over the next 3 years, and I suspect there could be some beyond that, too. But roughly, about 50% of that C
componenttext: Yes, so it's in our capital that we disclosed there for the 3 years, there's a good bit of integrity management related in that entire CapEx period over the next 3 years, and I suspect there could be some beyond that, too. But roughly, about 50% of that CapEx is related to integrity management in 2016 through 2018. Now some of that would be picked up with the midyear CWIP, in the rate base. So we'll get about -- get half of the year when we make the -- actually have the discussions with the North Carolina Commission staff in the middle of the year. So we'll basically have the remaining half of 2016 and 2017 and '18, so. But it's roughly half of it, relates to integrity management.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Travis Miller at Morningstar.
componenttext: The next question is from Travis Miller at Morningstar.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You answered most of my clarifying questions on the nuclear stuff, BLRA, et cetera. Wondering, on the gas side. Obviously, you had really strong customer growth. Just wondering what that was doing to gas usage, and also then, the next step to gas margins
componenttext: You answered most of my clarifying questions on the nuclear stuff, BLRA, et cetera. Wondering, on the gas side. Obviously, you had really strong customer growth. Just wondering what that was doing to gas usage, and also then, the next step to gas margins at those businesses.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, Travis, in the 2 LDCs, they really get handled through mechanisms in different ways. So in North Carolina, there's the decoupler that handles any change in consumption and weather, et cetera, and it doesn't handle rate base, which is why we hav
componenttext: Yes, well, Travis, in the 2 LDCs, they really get handled through mechanisms in different ways. So in North Carolina, there's the decoupler that handles any change in consumption and weather, et cetera, and it doesn't handle rate base, which is why we have a rate case that we filed there now. In South Carolina, we have the Rate Stabilization Act, which is basically a streamlined rate review that happens after every repeating season at the end of March. And if there's more than 50 basis points variance and it's suggested in November. So it's really considered through both of those mechanisms, even though they differ a little in their process.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, that customer growth, where we see that kind of 2.5% type rate. Does that mean substantial investment opportunity, either distribution or other value chain parts over the next couple of years, in addition to what you've already planned?
componenttext: Okay. And then, that customer growth, where we see that kind of 2.5% type rate. Does that mean substantial investment opportunity, either distribution or other value chain parts over the next couple of years, in addition to what you've already planned?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I'd say -- I wouldn't say a lot more than what we've planned. So what we've got in the plan now contemplates it. So in North Carolina and South Carolina, they differ somewhat. In South Carolina, we own very little of the transmission system. Of
componenttext: Yes. Well, I'd say -- I wouldn't say a lot more than what we've planned. So what we've got in the plan now contemplates it. So in North Carolina and South Carolina, they differ somewhat. In South Carolina, we own very little of the transmission system. Of course, we used to own more of it through a different subsidiary but we sold that a year ago. There is still some transmission in the South Carolina Electric and Gas, gas system, but it's not a tremendous amount. There's certainly distribution growth there in the South Carolina system, but that's not a significant amount above and beyond the depreciation that applies to that business each year. In North Carolina, it's a different story because of significant transmission enhancements that are going on. I actually visited one of those projects a couple of weeks ago, and it's a significant pipeline investment that's going on, and it's going extremely well. The majority of it own existing right-of-way in Western North Carolina.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and that could lead to distribution investment options?
componenttext: Okay, and that could lead to distribution investment options?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the majority of this is related to growth in the territory. The areas we serve are growing very well. A lot of transmission enhancement in the next couple of years will be up in the Research Triangle area, too, in addition to Western North Ca
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the majority of this is related to growth in the territory. The areas we serve are growing very well. A lot of transmission enhancement in the next couple of years will be up in the Research Triangle area, too, in addition to Western North Carolina, because a lot of the industrials are really going, for example, the research universities are all going to complete gas supply, as opposed to other fuels. So I don't know if there's tremendous, new frontier kind of distribution opportunities, but I think there's a lot of industrials that are really pushing it. Electric-fired, gas-fired, electric generation, too.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Dan Jenkins, State of Wisconsin Investment Board.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Dan Jenkins, State of Wisconsin Investment Board.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give a little color on the -- you had the $0.04 year-over-year for O&M, and I was wondering is that -- what's driving that? Is that timing? Or is that something that's going to continue on a comparison basis going forward?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give a little color on the -- you had the $0.04 year-over-year for O&M, and I was wondering is that -- what's driving that? Is that timing? Or is that something that's going to continue on a comparison basis going forward?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's fairly consistent with our internal budget. It is a little more lumpy there in the first quarter. We don't expect it to be that significant throughout the year. The most significant thing is we make compensation adjustments in the middle of the f
componenttext: No, it's fairly consistent with our internal budget. It is a little more lumpy there in the first quarter. We don't expect it to be that significant throughout the year. The most significant thing is we make compensation adjustments in the middle of the first quarter. So you've got some of that coming through. And also, of the incentive-based compensation, the part that's driven by -- that's driven off share price, has obviously been more than we had expected, and I guess, that's a high-class problem to have, with the stock performing pretty well especially against the peer group over the last quarter.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I think you mentioned on the nuclear that the current critical path item is the shield building, and I know that you know, in your last report that you filed in February that was mentioned there as well. I was wondering if you could update
componenttext: Okay. And then, I think you mentioned on the nuclear that the current critical path item is the shield building, and I know that you know, in your last report that you filed in February that was mentioned there as well. I was wondering if you could update us on the status of that, and in terms of the components that are being fabricated, and so forth.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, the shield building is going probably better than we had anticipated. Our concern for the shield building really came from the contractor, their concerns at the time that was Chicago Bridge & Iron. Now Fluor has taken over, but we still retain t
componenttext: Yes, Dan, the shield building is going probably better than we had anticipated. Our concern for the shield building really came from the contractor, their concerns at the time that was Chicago Bridge & Iron. Now Fluor has taken over, but we still retain the CB&I services crew that is doing that welding. So even though CB&I power exited the consortium, the CB&I services folks, who are doing the containment vessel welding and the shield building welding stay, and they're doing a tremendous job. So we've got -- there's about 16 courses of this steel that goes up to form the shield building. You lay a course at a time, weld it together then fill that course with concrete. So we've got 3 of those courses that have been placed, welded and filled with concrete. The fourth course has been placed. It's being welded. We anticipate filling that with concrete sometime in the next couple of weeks. The deliveries are coming in from an entity called Newport News Industrial, NNI, in Virginia, and those folks are working very hard to meet our schedule, and we're looking at diversifying that supply chain a little bit, by perhaps moving some of those modules to another vendor to free up a little bit of space at NNI. So overall, I'd say the shield building has gone a little bit better than we expected.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: How many of those components are you still waiting on the shield building?
componenttext: How many of those components are you still waiting on the shield building?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say there's 4 -- the first unit, Unit 2, we've probably got 2/3 of the shield building panels that we need. And for the trailing unit, Unit 3, we probably only have about 1/3 of them, and so we're still waiting on about 2/3.
componenttext: I would say there's 4 -- the first unit, Unit 2, we've probably got 2/3 of the shield building panels that we need. And for the trailing unit, Unit 3, we probably only have about 1/3 of them, and so we're still waiting on about 2/3.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on Unit 3, what's the current critical path item for that unit?
componenttext: Okay. And then on Unit 3, what's the current critical path item for that unit?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It runs through the shield building as well, Dan. So it's still shield building, either unit we're talking about, it runs through the shield building.
componenttext: It runs through the shield building as well, Dan. So it's still shield building, either unit we're talking about, it runs through the shield building.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Paul Patterson, Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: The next question is from Paul Patterson, Glenrock Associates.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask you about the fixed price option. And if you were to select that, what the impact is, in terms of -- does it change the way the payments would go? Could you just elaborate a little bit more on that?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask you about the fixed price option. And if you were to select that, what the impact is, in terms of -- does it change the way the payments would go? Could you just elaborate a little bit more on that?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Paul, from a payment perspective, as Jimmy alluded to earlier, we are changing the way that we make the payments. Heretofore, we've had payments based on either hitting milestones or what we call progress payments. Progress payments is a bit of a mis
componenttext: Yes. Paul, from a payment perspective, as Jimmy alluded to earlier, we are changing the way that we make the payments. Heretofore, we've had payments based on either hitting milestones or what we call progress payments. Progress payments is a bit of a misnomer. It really wasn't tied to actual progress. So we've changed that and when we go forward, we are negotiating a milestone payment schedule. So it's a construction milestone payment schedule, which will have us paying only for milestones achieved.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and does -- but it means, I guess, what I'm wondering is, is in terms of the -- you guys have not decided on whether or not you're going to go for the fixed price option. Is that correct?
componenttext: Okay, and does -- but it means, I guess, what I'm wondering is, is in terms of the -- you guys have not decided on whether or not you're going to go for the fixed price option. Is that correct?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and if you were to go for it, does that change the payments? Or does that change the schedule on payments? Do you pay anything upfront? Or is it pretty much the same way, would you be paying over the same time frame, pretty much the same amount with
componenttext: Okay, and if you were to go for it, does that change the payments? Or does that change the schedule on payments? Do you pay anything upfront? Or is it pretty much the same way, would you be paying over the same time frame, pretty much the same amount with this milestone? That's it.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So what -- so Paul, what we've done is, we've got an estimate for what is the nonfixed price option. If we elect the fixed price option, there's an added cost that comes with taking that risk away, if you will, and so what we'll do is we'll just pay
componenttext: Yes. So what -- so Paul, what we've done is, we've got an estimate for what is the nonfixed price option. If we elect the fixed price option, there's an added cost that comes with taking that risk away, if you will, and so what we'll do is we'll just pay that additional cost. It'll be stretched out over the entire project. So there's -- it's -- it won't necessarily be front-end loaded. We're just picking the milestones, which indicate real progress. We'll attach payments to those milestones, and when the -- Westinghouse hits those milestones, we'll make payment to them, but the additional cost just gets spread out over the remainder of the project.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Andy Levi at Avon Capital.
componenttext: The next question is from Andy Levi at Avon Capital.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'm just going to go back to Toshiba, because I just want to get something clarified, because if you were to choose the fixed cost option, which seems to be the right way to go, and obviously, you've got rid of CBI, so, now that was a very good t
componenttext: I guess, I'm just going to go back to Toshiba, because I just want to get something clarified, because if you were to choose the fixed cost option, which seems to be the right way to go, and obviously, you've got rid of CBI, so, now that was a very good thing that you guys did, and have Fluor in there. But given Toshiba's continued financial issues and concern about the companies, or our concerns and I guess, sell-side analyst concerns about the long-term viability of the company, can you tell us what type of projections you have in place to protect SCANA and the summer [ph] project from Toshiba's potential insolvency, relative to the fixed cost contract and their ability to execute on that? And then, can you get more into also the surety bond that you have, the amount that you have, and how that would work if you had to call on that? Because we saw Portland General having to call on their surety bond with Abengoa and it just wasn't that simple.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. Andy, this is Steve. Let me start, and I'll let Jimmy to finish, maybe a little bit on the surety bond, but the surety bond, as you pointed out earlier was there, really to create kind of a soft landing. So it would pay vendors that were
componenttext: Okay, all right. Andy, this is Steve. Let me start, and I'll let Jimmy to finish, maybe a little bit on the surety bond, but the surety bond, as you pointed out earlier was there, really to create kind of a soft landing. So it would pay vendors that were in process and allow us to, in a systematic, logical fashion, wind the project down to the point where Toshiba and/or Westinghouse could exit. Now if we're presuming some kind of insolvency or bankruptcy, you'd also have to presume that Westinghouse doesn't survive that, and so, as a, with that provision then, as you're aware, there can be various kinds of bankruptcy and it doesn't necessarily mean that the contractor stops working, but -- so we're working hard to make sure that we're not in advance of payments, and then we have information, which includes source codes, software and proprietary design information that's being escrowed, and the bankruptcy or insolvency would be one of the triggers that gives me that information, and then we would look to finish the plan on our own. We could do that one of a couple of ways: We could either act as our own general contractor, which we would be more comfortable doing now than when we originally signed up for the project since we've made so much progress, and we understand that this construction progress. And we would go out and get a subcontracted construction vendor, presumably Fluor, since they're already on-site, already familiar with that means and methods, and know the project; or we could EPC it again. So we could give it to an EPC contractor. Certainly Fluor would be in a good position. They are an EPC contractor. So we could give it to them. So the important part to me is that I have the information that I need to be able to finish the plant on my own, and that's whole reason why we're escrowing.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I guess, the issue that I see though is, I guess, the thing that was a big positive was this fixed cost contract, right? Because it kind of eliminates certain downside above the $500 million escalation in the cost of the contract, and so if that contr
componenttext: But I guess, the issue that I see though is, I guess, the thing that was a big positive was this fixed cost contract, right? Because it kind of eliminates certain downside above the $500 million escalation in the cost of the contract, and so if that contract is within entity that is not a good counterparty, that fixed cost contract is not really worth a lot, I guess, and that's what I'm really getting at is, not as much the ability to finish the plan or its construction aspect of it, but the ability to control the costs if in a negative case, Toshiba doesn't have the money to pay above the $500 million escalation that you're willing to pay in a fixed cost option.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier, Andy, the -- what we have on our side, though, is some time to watch how they progress, and to see how that's going. We've got another 6 months before we got to make this call. They have said publicly that this business is one of
componenttext: Well, as I said earlier, Andy, the -- what we have on our side, though, is some time to watch how they progress, and to see how that's going. We've got another 6 months before we got to make this call. They have said publicly that this business is one of 3 key areas of focus for them, and they're shedding the other businesses. They brought in $6.5 billion, or will, as soon as those sales close here shortly. Everything they have said they're going to do, it appears they've done to this point in a very efficient manner. So we've got several more months to watch this and monitor the situation.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just get concerns, I see stock trading, a little over $1. And then, just on the surety bond, could you just go over that, and the amount of that and how that would work, and who would be paying you?
componenttext: Yes, I just get concerns, I see stock trading, a little over $1. And then, just on the surety bond, could you just go over that, and the amount of that and how that would work, and who would be paying you?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's, it's actually, we -- it can be either in a surety bond or in letters of credit. We've allowed them to provide that through letters of credit, and we're comfortable with counterparties there, and it is an annual calculation based upon the est
componenttext: Yes, so it's, it's actually, we -- it can be either in a surety bond or in letters of credit. We've allowed them to provide that through letters of credit, and we're comfortable with counterparties there, and it is an annual calculation based upon the estimated quarterly payments in the next year. So we've made that calculation for 2016. We've elected it, and those letters of credit are in place now.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And who's the letter of credit with -- is it funded, the letter of credit? How does that work?
componenttext: And who's the letter of credit with -- is it funded, the letter of credit? How does that work?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a letter of credit in case they default on any of the provisions.
componenttext: It's a letter of credit in case they default on any of the provisions.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's for $100 million? Is that for $100 million?
componenttext: And that's for $100 million? Is that for $100 million?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's at a maximum of $100 million, based upon the projected cash flows of the year that's applicable, and so it will change each year.
componenttext: It's at a maximum of $100 million, based upon the projected cash flows of the year that's applicable, and so it will change each year.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, as far as on the creditors side, if Southern also has a fixed cost contract, according to them. I mean, I guess, I mean, who would get paid first, I guess, we don't know that, right? I mean, because Southern would have to see the same issue.
componenttext: And then, as far as on the creditors side, if Southern also has a fixed cost contract, according to them. I mean, I guess, I mean, who would get paid first, I guess, we don't know that, right? I mean, because Southern would have to see the same issue.

componenttext: I don't mean on the surety bond. I'm talking about, as far as the ability for Toshiba to perform on a fixed cost contract.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Hi, actually it's David Paz. Just a quick question on your long-term growth rate. What earned ROEs are you assuming, both at the SCE&G business and the PSNC business?

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so at SCE&G, David, we're consistent on the base business at above 9% is our strategy, to stay out of any base rate increases outside of the BLRA. And the BLRA of course, is at 10.5%, and at PSNC, we've got a current allowed 10.6%.
componenttext: Yes, so at SCE&G, David, we're consistent on the base business at above 9% is our strategy, to stay out of any base rate increases outside of the BLRA. And the BLRA of course, is at 10.5%, and at PSNC, we've got a current allowed 10.6%.

headline: SCANA Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So even in the PSNC case, we should think about, even though rate base is growing faster than in the past, you still anticipate somewhere in that mid-10s, earned ROE through your growth -- through the period of your long-term growth rate?

componenttext: Well, we've asked for 10.6% in the case. We'll have to wait and see how that situation comes out, either through negotiations or through hearing with the Commission. But we'll know that in another -- within 6 months.
